alert.note: Alert for Hatteras Island; Northern Outer Banks (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Coastal Flood Advisory issued September 27 at 8:59PM EDT until September 28 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City
info.description: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT THROUGH THURSDAY EVENING... ...COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 PM EDT THURSDAY... ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY IS CANCELLED... * WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves in the surf zone. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to one to two feet of inundation above ground level in low- lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. * WHERE...Northern Outer Banks and Hatteras Island. * WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Thursday evening. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 10 PM EDT Thursday. * IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is possible in some areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. A few road closures will be possible. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Time of high total tides are approximate to the nearest hour. Duck NC MLLW Categories - Minor 5.5 ft, Moderate 6.0 ft, Major 6.5 ft MHHW Categories - Minor 1.8 ft, Moderate 2.3 ft, Major 2.8 ft Total Total Departure Day/Time Tide Tide from Norm Waves Flood ft MLLW ft MHHW ft ft Impact -------- --------- --------- --------- ------- -------- 27/07 PM 6.4 2.7 2.1 8 Moderate 28/07 AM 6.1 2.4 1.9 7 Moderate 28/07 PM 5.8 2.1 1.5 6-7 Minor 29/08 AM 5.7 2.0 1.2 5 Minor 29/08 PM 5.4 1.7 1.2 5 None 30/09 AM 6.0 2.3 1.4 5 Moderate &&
info.instruction: If travel is required, allow extra time as some roads may be closed. Do not drive around barricades or through water of unknown depth. Take the necessary actions to protect flood-prone property. Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired, float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or wave for help. Shore break occurs when waves break directly on the beach. It is extremely important to protect your head and neck whenever you are in breaking waves by keeping your hands in front of you at all times.
